headline: Southern Methodist University hosts 'The Five'
subHeadline: 15 days ahead the midterms, 'The Five' takes the show on the road to broadcast live from SMU's campus in Dallas, Texas.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Lawrence Jones, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, 4 o'clock in Dallas, Texas, and this is The Five. Welcome to "The Five" live from Dallas. We're here on the campus of Southern Methodist University for the whole hour. The SMU Mustang band is playing for us. We have a great show. There's a ton of tight races to talk about in the midterms, the migrant caravan is getting even bigger as President Trump threatens to stop it. Plus, we're answering questions from some of the students in the crowd, and Lawrence has some big surprises for us that he brought back from the Texas state fair. So, Greg, how is Texas treating you so far?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: I love it. Although, I will say a marching band is not good for the hangover.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not at all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You had sweet tea last night.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: As the worst thing that you could possibly hear when your head is just reeling from pain. But this is -- we've got all guys, one girl. This is like out-lumbered.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Boy, you're hilarious.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That joke takes a while to figure out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I, for one, love a marching band.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I love the marching band. Thank you for being here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, do you feel welcome here in the great state of Texas or what?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Hey, you know what? Someone else said they're the lone star. I think that was Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I feel like -- and also, what fun it is to be right next to the stadium. Man, I tell you what, SMU football.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: People know about the Mustangs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There's definitely no kneeling going on in that stadium.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, that was huge, by the way. Their bathrooms are massive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Their bathrooms are dark and large.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: I know that we have a lot of Fox News supporters here in the great state of Texas because we defend liberty here, they believe in the president. They believe in what we're doing in Fox News.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: So, yes, it's good to be back home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They also buy a lot of our books.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know they say everything is bigger in Texas, including Greg's ego.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. There's a lot to cover, so let's just go right to it. With just 15 days to go, President Trump's approval rating hits an all-time high. Surging fast in the national poll. This comes as the president heads to Houston, Texas, tonight, for what's expected to be a massive rally for Senator Ted Cruz. Supporters began lining up over the weekend to get a good spot, and the president's 2020 campaign says 100,000 people have RSVP. Amid these positive signs for Republicans, President Trump very confident going into the midterms.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I think the Republicans are going to do very nicely. We're doing very well with the senate, and he was just asking about the race. Other than two years ago, the presidential race, I have never seen spirit like I see right now. I think the Republicans are going to do very well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, Democrats tamping down expectations of a so-called blue wave.

utterances.speaker: TOM PEREZ, DNC CHAIRMAN
utterances.sentences: You always knew that this election was going to be close. I don't use the term blue wave. I still have a lot of confidence in the house. I know the senate is a tougher map but we've got great candidates. And then I look at these governors' races and I see the work that's being done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, Dana, the generic congressional matchup ballot is shrinking now down to single digits, primarily if you look at the average. And then the competitive races, very tight. What do you think about this so-called blue wave at this point?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think that it's not possible in the Senate. I think the Republicans will keep the Senate and they will add to their numbers there. So that is -- it's just a tough year for Democrats. That math is hard. But guess what, it doesn't get any better for them in 2020, really, because of where the states are that you have contests. So turnout will be important and you might be able to tell a lot about 2020 once we finalize this midterm election. But in the house, I can't tell if the Democrats are doing a little bit of tamping down expectations because they want their people to get worried so that they will try to boost turnout or if it's kind of just demoralizing. They have all this build up, and now here you have Tom Perez, the DNC head saying, yeah, I never thought it's really going to be that good anyway. I don't think they'll be a blue wave. Does that just demoralize them even further and they not turnout, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How can the Democrats be demoralized even further, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, the blue wave is now -- officially a blue trickle. I think the Democratic Party need a giant box of depends because they are leaking everywhere. Here's why. You know what the Democratic Party is like, they're like the guy who shows up at the bar who wears too much aftershave, he's got his shirt open, he's trying really hard but he's guilty of overreach. Everything the Dems have done is overreach. Kavanaugh, overreach. Stormy Daniels, overreach. The caravan, overreach. They try so hard and it blows up in their faces because nobody takes them seriously. They have absolutely no results. They just have anger and emotion.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Juan, tone down the aftershave, all right. You're scaring everybody off. What do you think about this now coming from the head of the DNC trying to lower expectations?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it's smart. I think what you want to say to your Democratic base that has a tremendously high level of enthusiasm is, don't take anything for granted. Don't get complacent. You better get out there and vote. But, you know, let's go back to the top of the show. You were talking about Trump's numbers going up, now exceeding President Obama back in 2010.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But remember, Obama lost 63 seats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wasn't a good year.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm glad you mentioned that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was not a good year.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because there's a lot of people out there who were cheering you, Jesse, and I just want them to know the truth. And the second thing is, high-level.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But they all have great taste behind us.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, they do. They have great barbeque. But, you know, I think, remember, there's high levels of enthusiasm where, in fact, right now, a record level of enthusiasm for this midterm race. And a lot of it, I think, is generated by the fact that people think there's a lot at stake and there certainly is. I agree with Tom Perez, the map for the senate, very difficult. But I think right now for the house if you look at the numbers, things look pretty good for the Democrats, but they need their voters to turn out. And in a state like Texas, who thought that a Democrat could challenge Ted Cruz? That's the story.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I think the Democrats overplayed their hand. This is why they're struggling so much. And they never quite got a message. Everything was what they were against. You could never determine what their why was. And right now they're getting Republicans to the polls. The biggest advantage they had was Republicans were complacent. They got the tax cut that they wanted. They may be angry at congress for not getting health care, but they were going to stay at home. With the Kavanaugh stuff and the mob mentality that they have with socialism, now Republicans, especially in the state of Texas, are fired up and they will be going to the polls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now, Juan mentioned Beto O'Rourke, and I believe the president had some words for the Democratic senate candidate here. Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I think Beto O'Rourke is highly overrated. When I heard about him, I figured he must be something a little special. He's not. I thought he got beaten badly in the debates. I think he's a highly overrated guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. He also said something about Ted Cruz and it looks like there may be a nickname change. Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He's not Lying Ted anymore. I call him Texas Ted. Ted Cruz and I had a very, very nasty, tough campaign. It was very competitive. It was a very tough campaign.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So, overrated O'Rourke and beautiful Ted.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, see -- he was trying something out there and then he said Texas Ted, like he wants the alliteration. I don't think I would have gone with overrated or work. I would have used Beto, right? Because it's actually is an interesting topic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What? Beto male? Or you just call him the master.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Really good at his job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, it's too late. It's too late.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I've got it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Lying Ted is going nowhere and he's now having regrets. So he wants to live in the moment and say, oh, beautiful, beautiful Ted. Get out of here.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: The problem with Beto is he's running a national campaign. Texans hates that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: And so the fact that he wants to make this a social media campaign and opus to national politics, he just doesn't understand Texas.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, imagine Donald Trump running a social media campaign. Never heard of such.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Well, he's the president of the United States. You're making my point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Lawrence said that Texas is its own state. I hear Texas is its own country. Up next, a massive migrant caravan headed for the U.S. nearly doubles in size as President Trump promises to get tough to stop it. That and more as The Five continues from Southern Methodist University.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to "The Five" live in Dallas, Texas. A caravan of Central American migrants is reportedly swelling in size to about 7,000 people as it pushes north toward the U.S. border. In response, President Trump is threatening to cut off foreign aid to Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador if they don't stop this massive group. Trump is also clashing with the media over who is in the caravan and who is to blame.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know what you should do, just go into the middle of the caravan, take your cameras and search. OK. Search. No, no, take your -- take your camera, go into the middle and search. You're going to fight MS-13. You're going to find Middle Eastern. You're going to find everything. And guess what, we're not allowing them in our country. What's happening at the border was caused by the Democrats because they won't let anybody change immigration laws that are horrible.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Lawrence, criminal, MS-13, caused by the Democrats? What's going on?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Because the Democrats believe in open borders.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, is that right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I don't understand how you all can be competitive in border states such as Texas, advocating for illegals to come across the border.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think anybody.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: But quite frankly, we don't know who's in that crowd that's coming across the border, but that's just the fact. The American people don't want people coming across the border without vetting, right? That's the problem.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, Jesse, do you agree? Do you think that the president is demonizing these people who are seeking asylum?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, the president is telling the press to do its job and report the facts. Listen, we are a melting pot but we're also a nation of laws. And we don't like people kicking down the border and demanding citizenship. We want it done the right way and the proper way. And there's a lot of fake news about the caravan too. They're making it out to be a bunch of mothers with young children. But if you look at the video, you know, your eyes aren't going to lie to you. There's teenage kids. There's 20-year- old men. And they brutally broke through the border into Mexico, roughed up some of the border police on the Mexican side. They're wearing t-shirts that are calling our president the devil. And a lot of people in America are looking at these visual and saying this looks like a hostile crew. And we're not necessarily going to welcome you with open arms if you're going to behave that way. And then once they get a little north, they pay the drug cartels $5,000 for a family unit, so now the drug cartels are basically acting like tollbooth operators for America. So if the Democrats want open borders, they're on the same side as the drug cartels. Mexico has to step up and stop this. America would never let other citizens flow through our country in a caravan size the way Mexico is doing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, President Lopez overdoing it in Mexico, Dana. They say people in the caravan aren't leaving for pleasure. They're leaving out in necessity, about desire for the American dream, economic opportunity. And then the Democrats are saying, oh, President Trump is demonizing those people seeking asylum. What do you say?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think this entire episode -- if Democrats think that the caravan is helping their cause, they're wrong. If you are somebody who wants more legal immigration in the country, if you think that immigration is our strength, this is not helping. You take someone like me, very sympathetic to refugees. This, to me, does not look like refugees. And also, you have able-bodied young men. I understand that the economic conditions in their country are not good, but then stay there and fight for it, OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like we don't have to be responsible for that. And I am one -- I would take a lot more refugees, actual refugees. I think that that is an important thing than America does for the world. I think it's a leader on that. But this is -- this is not -- now, take somebody like me who is pretty moderate on immigration from that standpoint and you have me feeling this way about this caravan, then you've got a real problem. It's not helping you.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: They'll fight the Border Patrol but they won't fight for their own country, which is sad. Meanwhile, they'll send their kids across the border with the cartel many times. If anybody has done research on human trafficking, a lot of these kids that their parents send them across the border end up as sex slaves. But they want us to be compassionate when they end up behind bars. I mean, it's absurd.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Greg, a lot of threat now from the president saying he's going to cut foreign aid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But if you cut foreign aid to these countries, don't you worsen the conditions and make it more likely that people are seeking asylum?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. In fact, I think that this is the worst possible visual the Democrats have right now, unless, like, Bernie Sanders came out wearing a thong. Other than that, this is like -- you can't -- this is -- this crystallizes the lack of process.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Bernie bros might like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah. The process is a system, due process. That's what we want. What this is saying we don't care. We just have a goal. We want these people to come. If they so believe in the system of our government, why are they violating it so brazenly while holding onto their flag and talking about how great their country is as they're storming our border? Our border is what defined a country. It's crazy. And to the point about how -- Trump demonizing other people, who's been demonized the most? Every time you try to come out for some kind of process, they call you heartless or racist. Maxine Waters told people to go after Republicans and conservatives, and that is essentially demonization. So the demonization thing it goes both ways.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But isn't it process that people come to the border and apply?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not in that way. That's not a process.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think they have a right to apply.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: At the port of entry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. A new study reveals who is the most politically biased on college campuses. The answer ahead on "The Five" live from Dallas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ah, my head. All right, a new study found that among campus administrators, liberals outnumber conservatives by 12 to 1.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Knock it off. To put that in perspective, North Korea has more diversity. The result is a student body going deeper into debt and only exposed the one kind of thinking, the kind that makes kids dumber, so they don't notice it's also making them broke. So let's try some college-level math. The number of college administrators has doubled in the last 25 years. The only thing growing faster is Jesse's hair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And it's his real hair, by the way. Meanwhile, student debt now tops $1.5 trillion. That's 37 grand per kid. Now what do you get for that? A stupidity farm kept afloat on the backs of students and their parents. And because they're not learning anything of practical value, it's true, students won't realize this, of course. $1.5 trillion, it's basically our own Venezuela, a third world socialist sinkhole existing within the United States, immune to market forces and common sense, and you and your kids are paying for this crap. If you're 23, you won't be able to afford a home and you can't get married until you're done paying for the promos new butt lift. It's not a bad thing. What a bargain. You're getting poorer and dumber all for the same price. How stupid can you get? Go to college and for a mere 37 grand, you'll find out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hmmm.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. So I think the.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Maybe SMU is the exception?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, the message I'm trying to get to the college kids, Dana, is that it's a waste of time. Dropout right now. And everything will be great, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: How about don't listen to Greg yet, but be aware, and you should know -- the cost, right? Like what is the benefit, what is the value that you're getting? What are you paying for? And hold those administrators to.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And to be fair, SMU is a great school. But a lot of these.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, Jesse, these kids are going to be paying for four years of nothing for the rest of their lives.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. If I'm a father and I'm paying 60 grand for my kid to get brainwashed, I'd just rather have them watch CNN for free.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'll yank them right out of there. And listen, remember when Ward Churchill, the crazy left-wing professor in Colorado, he said people on 9/11 deserved to die, and it took that university like ten years to boot him out because he had tenure. I was just at Cornell asking why is Cornell so liberally biased? And they kicked me out. So it's totally backwards. It's snowflake city. They need safe spaces to do anything anymore. If we ever fight a real war, who's going to fight it? Not these guys. Maybe these guys.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, you've got to admit, 12 to 1 is groupthink, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And I think what we need is affirmative action for academic underachievers on the right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I tell you what, I so disagree with you because I think parents and students are paying for high-level education. They believe in education. They believe in the benefits of it. And if you go to the books, let's go to the numbers, guess what? College graduates make more.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Over their lives.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah. But it's not worth it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, they're also going to have -- they're going to be late buying a home, late buying a second car, but they also will have all the debt that the baby boomers and Generation X are putting on them for.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Hey, Greg. Seriously, Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Would you rather your kid go to college or not?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Peter Thiel has a great idea, these $100,000 grants where you -- start a business in two years instead of going to college. I think that -- it's better to learn how to open a business. Lawrence?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: So I have some numbers of myself. I cover this every day at campus reform. All right. So, SMU, love you guys. We pulled the FEC reports from SMU over 2017 to 2018, $85,000 went out, all right. $65,000 of that went to Democrat organizations.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You mean these are financial contributions?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Financial contributions. These are faculty, administrators, professors that are on the college campuses. So if they're giving towards the Democrats, all right, 100 percent of the donations, 65 percent of them are faculties, 13,000 of them was the administrator as well. If they're giving to Democrats, what do you think they're teaching the students?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think they better be teaching academics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, Juan, when I was at Harvard University doing a little Watters' World package the other day, I asked these two girls what do you think about the fast and furious scandals? And you know what they said? The movie? They don't even know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Not being exposed to right-wing conspiracies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Someone died.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: . San Diego state.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That is about impeaching Donald Trump? Do we really want to be teaching our students?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You don't think it's important to teach people about our Democratic process?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: To impeach Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I mean.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's not a headline. That's an actual course.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm saying that's a headline. That's the title of the course, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: But why should our students be.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, are you a snowflake? Are you so worried?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, and they do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They shouldn't be taking sides. It's an anti-Trump course.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: If you're saying it's an anti-Trump course, that's wrong.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It is. That's exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think so,

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Impeach Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, impeach.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, when we come back, we're going to be answering questions about the midterms from students here at SMU. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I sure love a marching band. I know my friend Maria is out there watching them, too, and she loves them, as well. Welcome back to "The Five," live in Dallas. College students could have a major impact on the midterm, so we're good to hear from some SMU students who have questions about the November election. I'm going to turn this way because they're here. Grace Reon, go ahead. Ask your question.

utterances.speaker: GRACE REON, SMU STUDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi. I'm a political science major and senior here at SMU; and my question is has O'Rourke appropriately adjusted his strategy and rhetoric for Texas audience? And does he need to?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Does he need to? Greg, you want to take that one?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I heard that he actually got a rifle rack for his Prius. But you know they have that saying that he's all hat, no cattle? He's like no cattle, all manure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Does anyone want to answer her question?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would say this. Didn't he come out for kneeling during the national anthem? So that's not going to play in Texas. So he needs to recalculate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what I think is interesting on this? Is that he's run, really, a high-class campaign in terms of lack of name-calling, until the debate, which is when I would say he's picked up on your question.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He may have gone negative too -- too late.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He picked up on the line. But you know what? I just think it's good. It's good, because it's hope and high-class, as opposed to fear and anger.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We've to keep going going, Lawrence, because we've got another one. We're going to have you go first next, Lawrence. Miles Beattie. Miles Beattie, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: MILES BEATTIE, SMU STUDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, I'm Miles Beattie, who -- I'm a sophomore, a Democrat who is voluntarily giving content to this network. And --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, we appreciate it. What's your question?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I know how you feel, Miles.

utterances.speaker: BEATTIE
utterances.sentences: I'm a little nervous, but --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Miles isn't getting paid, Juan.

utterances.speaker: BEATTIE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but my question -- my question is, do you believe the polls accurately represent the race, since many young people who are considered, quote, "unlikely voters" are fired up about O'Rourke?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Good question. Lawrence, you know a lot about college campuses and the campaign.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, and when I came back to Texas, there's a lot of Beto signs all over the place. I think Ted Cruz kind of got comfortable at first. He was running for president ever since he got elected to the Senate. And so he was a little far removed. Once he came back and started telling the people what he was for, why they elected them, I think the energy went back to Ted Cruz. I really don't think Beto ran a campaign for Texas. He ran a national campaign, as I said before. And so he really does focus on the issues. Cruz is going to focus on Texas. So, you know, I think the polls are wrong on this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And Miles we'll have to see turnout, because do signs and momentum turn into actual votes? We'll see. Everyone is going to be studying this race, because it will have impact in 2020, for sure. All right. Grayson, we're going to go to you next. This is Grayson Sumpter. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GRAYSON SUMPTER, SMU STUDENT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I'm a political science and prelaw student and the vice president of College Democrats. This is in reference, also, to the previous question. So considering that, as we've seen in particular in the last few years, polls don't always perfectly represent how people are going to vote. What factors do you think that pollsters are looking out for in determining these things?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan, you want to go first?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: One of the difficulties, is obviously, you've got to look at registered voters, and then you've got to look at likely people among registered voters. And that's the difficulty in a contest like the one here in Texas, where here we are on the campus of SMU. In most midterms, young people do not turn out. Minorities do not turn out to vote in high numbers. The question is, are they wrong this time because of the high level of engagement with these midterms. And one final factor, cell phones. I bet you don't have a landline. So if the pollsters are checking, do they miss you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And OK, we're going to go next to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Hey, try to make this a fun question, OK?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- John Bookas.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BOOKAS, SMU STUDENT
utterances.sentences: I can. All right. I'm from Fairfield, Connecticut. I'm a music and math major here, and I'm the president of College Republicans. I was wondering, what types of stories seem to have the greatest and least effect on the -- on the public?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A question for you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that, obviously, anything that has visual appeal will win. I mean, that is why I think the caravan thing has been so damaging. And any time that you actually -- when you see the overreach, like you did, Kavanaugh could have just came and went, but when they decided to go full -- when they went full Avenatti, or as I like to call him spaghetti Avenatti, because you serve him with a side of crow. The guy's life is over. He was supposed to have a rally today. Did you know that? He canceled it, because he couldn't afford the cab fare. Anyway, I don't have an answer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, about stories? Like, how do you make a story choice for what you want to do on "The Five" or "Watters' World"?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You've got to go visual. It's got to really blow you away emotionally and impact you like that. That's why the Russia story is a joke. No one can see it. You can't taste it. You can't hear it. It doesn't mean anything to anybody. It's just in the sky. So that's why that's not getting any play. I agree with Greg. The caravan is hot right now, because it burns your eyes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Imagine that. The Russia story has just gone away.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's fake news.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: These are very important, but also, you've got to remember to pay attention to when people tell the pollsters what their No. 1 issue is: health care. It's been all the way across the board. Republicans have been late to figure out a way to defend themselves on that. Let's go to the next one. We have Evie Mathis. Evie, get the microphone there. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: EVIE MATHIS, SMU STUDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, I'm from Boulder, Colorado, and I'm the vice president of College Republicans. I was wondering why do news stories, even big ones, tend to die out after a couple of days?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because Trump tweets something.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's actually kind of true. I think partly it's the 24/7 news culture. Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: The attention span of the viewers. I mean, there's always another news story. And sometimes that next news story outweighs the other one, and so the attention span of the viewer, they forget about it and move on to the next thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what it is? Do you ever play shuffleboard? That's what the news is now. So you go -- we put a little story out there and then somebody gets another story and bumps it out. So that's all news is now, is we keep bumping stories. Even we -- even stories that we have out there are bumped by another story.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it's just like a gusher these days. And so much is driven literally as Jesse says by the Trump Twitter feed. It just keeps coming.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. We're got to keep going.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You have to realize that you, as a smart young woman, SMU student, need to pay attention to stories that are important that will make a difference.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Indeed. All right. Emmakate Few. Not many, a few. Kate Few, go ahead, last question.

utterances.speaker: EMMAKATE FEW, SMU STUDENT
utterances.sentences: Thanks. I'm Emma Kate from Augusta, Georgia. I'm a journalism and political science student here at SMU. But I want to hear your take on if you think it's a good thing that athletes have a larger platform to speak about politics or if they should stick to sports.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not going to tell anybody bigger than I am what to do, because then they could just knock my head off. So they do what they want.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think you have to be straight with our FOX audience and tell them that you are an athlete. And you're a great runner. But you know what? I think it's just the celebrity world. And so if we have a celebrity president, why shouldn't celebrity athletes also have their say?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I'm just a free-speech purist. If you want to talk about politics, I don't care. It doesn't mean that I'm going to take their opinion, you know, into account, because they're professional athletes but I like athletes talking about sports.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think everyone should shut up except for me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Emmakate, I bet you didn't expect that answer. Thanks, students. We appreciate it. We love that you are here. And next, Lawrence hits the Texas State Fair to talk to voters about the midterms. He's got a big surprise for us next. Not sure what that is.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I'm so excited to be back here in Dallas. It's my hometown. I lived here my entire life here up until this past year. And one of my favorite things to do growing up was to go to the State Fair of Texas, which is just a few minutes away. Earlier today, I made my way down there, where I snatched up some surprises for you guys. And I also have the chance to speak with some Texans about the Texas big state Senate race. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Howdy, everybody. And welcome to Texas.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: All right. I'm going to conquer my fear today. I'm going to do this. It's going to swing me all around the place, but I think I'm ready to do it. You've got Ted Cruz versus Beto O'Rourke. Who's your favorite candidate and why?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ted Cruz. Just for philosophical reasons.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Definitely Beto, because he just brings new life into the system.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I think everybody needs to get out and vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to go with Beto, largely because I think the ways in which he's been able to, like, create a grassroots campaign.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm a constitutional conservative, so I'm a Cruz fan.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: What issue is most important to you?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The issue for me as an immigrant, of course, immigration is one.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: To me it's the deficit.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Party line. In all honesty, people say, they'll be, like, "Well, I'm going to vote for this candidate because I'm Republican, or I identify as a Democrat." But it doesn't matter. Issues are issues. My favorite thing at the fare is funnel cake and lemonade.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: and turkey legs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Turkey legs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The food, absolutely the food.

utterances.speaker: JONES (EATING SOME FOOD)
utterances.sentences: Woo! So good. I love Texas.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Very nice.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: God, I love my state. Right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Great job, Lawrence. Great job.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I brought you guys some goodies. This is fried pizza, so try it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Fried pizza? How can you fry a pizza?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Just eat it, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know about this one.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Just eat it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to pass this down to Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can you eat that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: And this is fried PB&J, all right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Peanut butter and jelly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, you want that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That looks good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I want the chocolate one, please.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, no. She wants the cookie dough.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. The fried cookie dough.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I swear, I ran over something like this last night.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I don't know what it is, but --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: This is fried cookie dough?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: These are fried Oreo cookies.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Let me tell you what I love about Texas.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I only smell it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: We season our food. We treat it with love. We love people. We're friendly, unlike D.C., where I was.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Ohh!

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: You know, this -- this trip was really good for me, because it reminded me of what I'm fighting for, which is the liberty that Texas has preserved. And I want -- I want the rest of the United States to experience this. Low taxes, no state tax. OK? So we want to keep more of our money.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. There's no state tax there?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: There's no state tax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm moving to Texas.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I told you. Right? And the people are just amazing here. Haven't you guys had a great time?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We had a great time. But I'm seeing you out there with big hammer. What happened?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Well, things happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I thought you won. I thought you won that big prize.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did win a prize, but I didn't get quite what I wanted. So I ate a lot of food. So blame it on the food, OK?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm rooting for you, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: On the kiddie ride, you looked a little scared.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I'm afraid of heights --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: -- but I conquered my fear. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just so you know, while you were doing that, Jesse was getting a facial.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was a barbecue facial.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Was it really a barbecue facial?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Infused.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is that what you're calling it?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: OK, the audience is waiting for us to eat this food.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't eat it!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I have another question.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, what's up?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Where did you get that hat? Is that a Texas hat?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's a Texas hat. I had to dust it off before I got on the plane. And I brought my cowboy boots. And yes, it's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you look.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You look great, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What did you study? Did you want to go into journalism, or what was it?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I was a criminal justice major, and I wanted to go to law school. My sophomore year, I started doing TV, and I've been doing it ever since.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then how did you -- tell us about Campus Reform, then. How did you get connected?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: So campus reform, I left my job here in Texas with the campus, and I really wanted to save the college campuses. We keep talking about all these issues that we're facing right now as a country. They start on the college campuses. Like the mob that you see right now, going over --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You went too far.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It started -- it started on the college campuses, where people just got away with everything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jobs not mobs, Juan. Jobs not mobs.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How about critical thinking, smart people asking questions?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm sure you love it, because it --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can't put that on a bumper sticker.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, holding politicians to account. We can't hold that on a bumper sticker.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's too many words.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: To you, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, but you're right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- the war.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what it is? Campus is like a seeping sore, and everything out of it goes out into pop culture, and all of a sudden, it ends up at the worst place, in human resources. It's all toxic ideas, and it has to be stopped. That's why don't go to college.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: But -- there's hope, though, because at Campus Reform, most of the reporters, all of them, actually, over 90 reporters, they're all college students. And they report on liberal bias and beefs every single day. So there's hope for us.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's pretty good. Well, thank you for bringing us this delicious food. I am not going to eat it. I'm just going to smell the calories. It smells really good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You just put on two pounds.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know. You can just, like, gain weight just smelling it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But anyway, thank you, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We've got to go.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Time now for a "One More Thing." Dana Perino.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. I just want to take a moment and thank our fantastic crew. Fox News always has the best people, and it's not the people here that you see on your screens; the people behind us. We have some pictures from before. All those guys there. Audio, lighting, stage manager. Look at these guys, all across the board. Last night we went to the Heartache Pit barbecue. We had our team there: our producers, audio, everybody. We appreciate it. If you want to see a little bit more about what's going on in Texas politics, go to the Facebook page for "The Daily Briefing." I did a Facebook live that you can watch, taped, with Gomer Jeffers Jr. He's a "Dallas Morning News" reporter. He knows everything about politics in Texas. Check it out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. As Dana said, last night we were at the Heartache Barbecue. Greg had way too many ribs, too much sweet tea. We shot a whole package for you guys. That package is going to air tomorrow night on "The Five," 5 p.m. Eastern, 4 p.m. Texas time. So make sure to check that out. You actually probably want to see what's edited out of this package.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's where it got really crazy. But anyway, we had a lot of good food and a lot of fun.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm still full.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So tune in. Yes, that's the whiskey pie right there. That's a must-get. All right. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, now for some real photography. Let's roll.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Gosh.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Airplane Pics!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Airplane Pics!" All right. When I fly, I tend to have a little drink on, a bottle or two of wine. And I know that when I'm on the plane, everything is really interesting to me. Like clouds. So let's just run some pictures of some clouds that I took. There's some clouds. You see that, that was during the takeoff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You've never seen clouds before.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: this was when we are coming a little bit up. I don't know where we were.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Cumulus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And then this is some more. Put -- the lower third is blocking the clouds. You crazy people. I have -- we have 30 of these.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Beautiful clouds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We have more clouds after that, and then we have yet more clouds, because I was drunk and I thought it was interesting. And now that I look at it, I'm deeply embarrassed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So are we, Greg. All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Much love, Gregory. We understand these things happen. Hey, a different look for "The Five" today. We got off the set and went into a classroom, a journalism classroom here at SMU. The students wanted to know about working at Fox, bias in the news business. They had a lot of questions about low levels of trust in American journalism and what they can do in the next generation to restore public confidence. The good news: the classroom was packed, folks. Tony Peterson, the chair of Journalism Department, and Pam Harris Hackett, who is in charge of broadcast journalism, told us enrollment for journalism right now: an all- time high at SMU. It was great to meet the students, and I told them, what they will do in delivering the truth, holding the powerful to account, is essential to the future of American democracy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They're coming for your job, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. No fake news here at SMU.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Terrence [SIC].

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Terrence? Lawrence!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Lawrence! OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I had too much wine with Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, blame me.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: One of my favorite things to do is eat sweets. My godmother has a bakery here in Dallas. Absolutely Edible Cake. And her favorite dish that everyone goes crazy about is the Sweet Potato Thang.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, she's cute!

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes. She's been on the Food Network channel.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What's the name of the bakery?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's Absolutely Edible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you think having the word "edible" in it is necessary?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I mean, is there bakeries where it's inedible?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: We don't judge. We don't judge.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm smelling it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, but it's the Sweet Potato Thang. People fight each other over this over Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Even the last -- I want to see your reaction when you have one bite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's pretty awesome.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I promise you won't regret it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is awesome.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is really good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm so full.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just eat it, Dana. Come on.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Even if you don't live in Dallas, you can go to Absolutely Edible, and she will ship you one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It is delish.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Right? Isn't it amazing?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. I like the mom plug in there. Got to respect that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Mom plug?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Lawrence, right?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's it for us from Dallas. Special thank you, a very special thanks to everyone here at SMU. We'll see you tomorrow back home in New York City. "Special Report" is up next. Play it away, boys.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
